Welcome & Installation

The following is documentation and examples of the Virgin Pulse animation library. To install in your project:

$ cd your_repo_root/repo_name
$ bower install --save virgin-pulse-animation

This will install the required files to the bower_components folder in your application, as well as update bower.json for future developers/build machines to use. Once the files are on your machine, simply include the file /bundled/jquery.cardeffect.js (or the minified version, found in the same directory) in your project.

Examples

Card Effect (Bubbles)

This animation will produce a burst of configurable bubbles from behind a div element. It can be used to draw attention to an element, or as a celebration for an action being successfully completed. Click on the card below to see the effect.

Click Me!

In order to accomplish this, some basic jQuery knowledge is required. Inside of your document.ready, there are two pieces for this animation effect. The first is the initialization of the animation, and the second is the animation trigger.

To get started, this is the example HTML structure:

<div class="cards">
  <div class="container">
    <div id="CardOne" class="card">
      <div class="content"><h1> Click Me!</h1></div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

Next, we initialize the animation and bind it to the HTML element, in this case the card.

$('#CardOne').initCardAnim({
  // Bubble color
  color: '#FC8D25',
  // Card content selector (within element)
  content: '.content',
  // CSS class for animation wrapper element (appended after content)
  wrapperClass: 'animation-layer',
  // CSS styles to apply to animation wrapper
  wrapperStyles: {
    'position': 'absolute',
    'top': '-100px',
    'bottom': '-100px',
    'left': '-100px',
    'right': '-100px',
    'z-index': '0'
  },
  // Speed of individual particle animation (ms)
  particleSpeed: 1200,
  // Number of particles
  particleCount: 100,
  // Do something after the animation finishes
  callback: function() {}
});

In this case, we are binding the animation to the #CardOne id, but the animation itself is targeting the .content class div. This is so that the animation knows which div to be contained inside (#CardOne) but also which div to hide behind (.content).

There are several available options, listed out in the example, and should be fairly self-explanatory.

Next, set up the trigger event, in this case clicking the card.

//Trigger animation on click
$('#CardOne').on('click', function() {
  $(this).triggerCardAnim();
});
